results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: Melons for Jam
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an instructional film on fruit preserving. Expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates the process for making melon jam in a domestic kitchen. This film is a fascinating insight into household kitchens and cooking in the 1950s, particularly before widespread international food import enabled greater fruit produce availability all year.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information

results.title: [Agnotes Advertisement: 4]
results.brief_description:
Victoria’s Department of Agriculture (now Agriculture Victoria) produced Agnotes, a series of reference material for the industry with the aim to disseminate expert advise for best agricultural practices.

This advertisement was designed to increase the uptake of the Agnotes by farmers. It is one of many commercials produced for the Department of Agriculture.

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Quilts of Understanding
results.creator_credit: Jenene Egan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
In this story, Jenene tells of her life-long passion for all things craft. Recounting one of her proudest moments, she speaks about some patches that she created for a collaborative quilt-making project, which was exhibited at her Uniting Church and throughout regional Victoria.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Generations of Hands
results.creator_credit: Jennette Moore and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Jennette was born in Ballarat. In this digital story, she talks about her personal experience growing up as a deaf person. She recalls learning how to sign and memories with her little brother and parents. Jennette also tells of her children (one of whom was sadly still-born) and grandchildren.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
